line.tr: /// for whole life accepted, gone to the support, [faithful] ///
/// O male lay-disciple! Which ... by the glorious one ///
/// by the one who has gone in this way, by the Arhat, by the one who has known completely (and) correctly ///
/// these should be learned by the male lay-disciple for whole life. ///
/// is the prescription for the male lay-disciple. Here by you for whole life ///
/// In any case you should not transgress the point of this kind. If you agree, ///
/// the keeping away (from taking away what is not given) is the prescription for the male lay-disciple. Here you (for whole life) ///
/// finally the pieces of the thread. (In any case you should not transgress) the point of this kind ///
/// (the keeping away) from ... (is the prescription for the male lay-disciple.) ///
/// ... (3 the keeping away from telling a lie) is the prescription [for the male lay-disciple]. ///

comments.comment: The name b4 iśva(radatte) suggests appurtenance to the manuscript A 144-211, where it is attested in a3, b1, b4, a5, b4 and a3.

knāṣ-äṃ: the correct interpretation of this form was given by , to which a reference is unfortunately lacking in (which appeared later). Pace , the form is not related to knā- 'know' (it is left with a question mark in ).
(puttiśpa)rṣṣāṃ: Other restorations are also possible. Unlike in this case, would usually expect a noun to be following this obl.sg.f. adjective.

translation.line: On day nine, klese of/for the kapyāri: ...
On day of the month ten, klese of/for the kapyāri...
The provision of Puśaiyśe: klese: three...
On day eleven, wākte for the kapyāri...
Flour of/for the weavers: five pints...
The Pañcwarike Indrarakṣite saw it. The Saṅkastere...
On day twelve, wākte of/for the kapyāri: two...

translation.line: During that very time, ... of the Moko Artatewe...
I gave coins: two hundred fifty...
In the seventh month, through the count of the Twātker,
they need one person of the Yurpāṣkans in the prefecture-city. However, no one went into the city. A/The person...
I gave coins: one hundred. There is a receipt from Nasuci...

comments.comment: reads this as twānkerräṣṣe or twānkerrṣṣe. She argues that it is a loan word from Chinese 团结 'civil corps', which would explain the use of 'nk' instead of 'ṅk'. However, this is phonetically awkward. It could be argued that the final -t of 结 is weakened, much like in intervocalic contexts in English. However, if this was the case, why did the scribe use 'rr' instead of 'r'? If no other examples of this phenomenon can be found, Ching's explanation rests on rather shaky grounds.
cf. THT 2852, , . This is a loan word from Chinese 抄 'receipt', which is also attested as čuv in Old Turkic and kṣau in Khotanese.

This Chinese character also occurs in the inscription Kz-221-ZS-D-06.

comments.comment: Ching suggests either suwañ or suwaṃ.
It could be the diminutive of kanti, but this wouldn't quite fit as a name.
The -ṣṣuki very much looks like an agent noun.
The missing akṣara could be 'ka'. Ching has '[pu]', but the 'pa' isn't visible.
The 'ṣṣu' is written with a horizontal line crossing through a vertical line, something that usually occurs in double 'kk'.

transcription.prose:
rawesi aksaṣuki wrā w· ·u ·ñ·
täṃ keś mā āś empelle palsko tswaśke pyāmtsar a kā rsa
naimaññe ṣkasne lyukesiś paikāwa

translation.line: ... count... don't make (your) head terrible (and your) thinking tswaśke(?)...
First month, on day six, I wrote to lyukesi(?)

comments.comment: Two hapax legomena, the latter transparently being an agent noun of āks- 'anounce, instruct'. The first one could be an infinitive of an unknown verb. Adams lists three seperate stems in ru-, of which none really fit the context; but ru- 'open' seems to be morphologically the best contender. But if lyukesiś is a personal name, rawesi might be too.
This seems to be a set phrase, where āś empelle and palsko tswaśke are parallel. Thus, we would expect tswaśke to mean something similar to empelle. Maybe it is related to tsu- 'adhere'.

recto.line: ki¯ ¯Ś te ske ma sa ṣu kta ka ta rya ta nā

transcription.prose:

(swām)i (a)śari śarsa ¤
·e ṣuk(t)a(ka)

translation.line: ... teske for the lamp was spent: seventy three...
... the lord ācārya knew about it ¤ ...

comments.comment: The only restoration that seems to both fit and make some sense is a form of tanākko 'grain', maybe in this case 'granule, seed'. This assumes that teske (or neske) is some sort of plant whose seeds can be used to make oil. However, it seems a bit strange to measure the amount of the plant by counting the individual granules. Therefore I have decided to make no restoration.

translation.line: ... on one picul (?) two pecks. We made silk ntāp...
... a picul, ten piculs, eight pecks...

comments.comment: ntāp is the word talked about by . kau appears to be the singular of kaumma, not **kaum as suggests. We are dealing with a plural in -nma, i.e. *kaunma. This regularly turns into *komnma/*kaumnma. Assuming a simplification of the cluster 'mnm' to 'mm', yielding komma/kaumma, is trivial. This also removes the need for the rather strange hypothesis of kauṣṣe 'made of silk' being derived from a different root. However, the etymology proposed for kauṣṣe in , i.e. that it is a loan word from Chinese 縞 'undyed silk', can be accepted, since we also know of other Chinese loan words which have a plural in -nma (e.g. cakanma).

recto.line: śa kwi ne śā nta w·

comments.comment: has eśyeṣṣe. The e-diacritic is only a miniscule stroke of ink; it's angle is also unusual for e: rotated to the right. Thus, it seems better to read ā. This would also be better morphologically, since this word is definitely related to THT 2689 eśyai, meaning eśyāṣṣe has the same relationship to *eśya as witsakāṣṣe to witsako. This is much more appealing than assuming an adjective derivation from an adjective derivation *eśyeṣṣe.
There's a visible kapci-mark, so this restoration is pretty secure.

comments.comment: Likely from Sanskrit ajñāta(ka) 'unknown', from which an abstract noun was derived by means of the Tocharian suffix -ñe (cf. upāsakñe)
Maybe a mistake for po śaiṣṣentse?

At first sight, surye looks like sa 10. However, I haven't been able to find another example of a '10' with something that looks like an e-diacritic on top of it (there are examples of 10 with a sort of hook). Thus I have concluded that the left part of the '10' is actually the u-diacritic of 'su', and that the '10' is actually a 'rye'.

comments.comment: This document is very peculiar. The first line doesn't make any sense. The second line has the phrase preksau yṣū... where the second word could be a form of yṣuwar 'friendly; friendliness'. This is reminiscent of the letters, cf. THT 492 a1 Āryawarmeṃ tsamo yṣuwarsa prekṣäṃ. This document could therefore be a letter. The writing ductus also bears some similarity to THT 2805. The 'ra's are L-shaped in both documents. However, they weren't written by the exact same hand.

comments.comment: sic! It is difficult to say why there isn't a genitive here.

This is most probably a nominative singular. The expected form would be oṅkorño. We are most likely dealing with the very common alternation between -o and -iye, cf. yoko - yokiye, ścono - śconiye, koṣko - koṣkīye.
Interpreting mitässi as the causative infinitive of mit- 'go'.
This fragment has the peculiarity that the virāma-dot is always on the akṣara preceding the akṣara that has virāma, i.e. wsa¯ ¯M has a dot above 'wsa', cā¯ ¯K above 'cā'. cf. THT 459 a9

Most likely a form of sanāp- 'rub, anoint'. Maybe a participle sasanāpau (cf. kākālākā-), but the accent would be strange.
